blog.title: The Rickshaw Passenger
blog.name: rickshawpassenger
blog.description: somewhere in rural India, I'm probably drinking chai

posts.body: Kolkata airport is modern and comfortable but still as bureaucratic as you’d expect.

As the mountains disappear behind the hills for the last time I find myself wishing I were going deeper into the mountains, staying just a little longer. But no, this trip is now unwinding, and I will follow the thread back home.
A man butchers a chicken in plain sight of the cage of other chickens on the side of the road. They take no interest and squabble over bits of grain as they await their turn.
It isn’t long before the vast plains of India with her mighty rivers appear, and descending to them we return to the heat, the clutter, and the horns.
Descending with my bag I found the mountain had bared its craggy head for us to see.
Finally had a good clear view of the mountains after a nice, early morning walk. The crisp air and expansive views should provide a nice contrast to the next 48 hours of airports and airplanes.
If you’d only had a croissant described to you over the phone you’d make it like this one.
Awaken to voices chanting “om”. Finally a clear enough morning to see the giants of the Himalaya if I sit just so in bed.

Sad I won’t be seeing the mutton-chopped Buddhist speakeasy proprietor from last night again. Instead, I’ve decided to retreat back up six flights of stairs to our quaint attic room to contemplate the last three weeks from the peace of a slant-ceilinged bathroom.
The two monks walking by in crimson robes with plaid umbrellas smile and wave back to me.
Thai for dinner. Giant bicycle parts statue of a Predator with a decapitated Alien by the door. Eight feet tall.
Up a narrow set of stairs on a whim into a school playground. Up another to a temple with singing and Ganesha at the door. Up another…
An excavator has left a large rock on the railway. No matter. The engine (after an exchange of words with the operator) powers through, pushing it aside.
Railway chai in the drizzle at a coal stained station in Ghoom on our little “Joy Train” ride.
A man sorts through the spent coal dumped by the engine for nuggets left unburned.
Quick catch up: we are in Darjeeling, former British outpost and now home to tea plantations, tourism, and trekking. It was from here that the first Everest summit attempts departed.
The train comes to a stop in the road through town. An engineer jumps out with a large hammer and starts hitting something under the train.
The 130 year old steam locomotive on the Darjeeling Himalayan Railway leaves with a jolt.
The Himalaya award very few unobstructed views out into the mountains, but Darjeeling drapes rather fetchingly downslope.
Felt too weird not updating the tumblr.
Thanks for reading, everyone. I had fun bringing you along on the trip with us. I might post a few more tidbits now and then but from here on in we’re just regular tourists in India.
Contemplating whether I sustained permanent hearing loss with a nice pot of coffee and an Indian breakfast.
Red red wine cover. Yup
This, by the way has been amazing and I would definitely do it again.
Conversations like radios to tune into. All the same channel, more or less. Local band playing in the banquet hall, but we’re drinking Tuborg in a big tent outside.
Soot stained travelers with stories and beers aplenty. Assault rifle armed police look on bemusedly.
Teams trickling in. Ten since we got here.
I think it’s fair to call it now: zero cases of Delhi Belly.

posts.caption: Jo, Tanis, and Lauren met us at the finish line.

posts.body: Came in under the most amazing rain storm. Rivers in the street.
All six of us going the hotel to drop off our bags. Quire cozy in the back seat.

posts.caption: Welcome to Shillong!

posts.body: Discussing a photo opportunity for the rickshaw while conducting our final refueling.
A rickshaw is traffic soluble.
Awful traffic into Shillong. Totally backed up on this mountain drive.
Passed Sitar Wars who have mastered the art of push starting their vehicle in traffic.
On the final ascent into Shillong.
Blow through the red light with all the rest of the traffic.
Awaken to the muezzin calling the city to prayer. Grey day. Should be cool, but might be wet.
Expensive hotel. No hot water. Sleep now and an early start for our final day.

posts.text: It tastes like I dropped it on the floor.

posts.body: Pulled into Guwahati after a long night drive. Tomorrow we close this sucker out.

Picture this: a dusty road at night. A dented blue pickup illuminated by head lights with a scooter tied down in the back. A man and his wife tucked in with it, hitching a ride. He’s a little worn, just like the truck, but she’s radiant under the dust and is dozing nestled into the crook of his shoulder. The back and forth of the road is almost like a cradle. He’s watching out the back of the truck as the wheels kick up a dusty Aurora Borealis.
Night falling. Near miss for a motorcycle when a front-loader clips it with his bucket. Still a ways from Guwahati.
Some kids swarm the rickshaw dressed in traditional clothes with a drum demanding who knows what, but we are very late to Guwahati and press on after some negotiations.
Soldiers form a bridge of hands on either side of the road to stop traffic and let us pass.
Sparse countryside. Surprised to discover I do not see a chai stand in any direction.
Roads improved. Bridges much worse somehow. We’ll be late into Guahati but are pressing on.
Roads are excellent now, but the bridges

Wound up in the middle of a military convoy. Artillery officers took pictures. A dour faced man with the most amazing mustache eyed us suspiciously from the back of his transport with his rifle on his shoulder. The others would wave each time we came close.
Our own hopes of reaching Guahati today are fading. Eating melted candy.
No joy from the carburetor repair, so we take our leave of the ladies and gents and head on our way after leaving them a bouquet of duct tape and zap straps as a condolence.
No joy from the carburetor repair, so we take our leave of the ladies and gents and head on our way after leaving them a bouquet of duct tape and zap straps as a condolence.
Then the army made a hole in the traffic jam for us by rearranging some trucks so we could go through.

posts.caption: Caught up with our friends from Suri broke down on the side of the road.

posts.body: Dog just in pieces on the highway. Another dog sniffing at the remains. Awful.
The gravel road fed directly into a pristine four lane highway.

posts.text: This pavement is like an orgasm.

posts.body: Rainwater masks the depth of potholes on the worst stretch of road we’ve seen in 4000km of driving.

posts.caption: Elephant on a leash.

posts.body: So close we can taste it. Ran into a team driving the opposite direction and had a quick powwow.
Man in bright orange monk’s robes says something unintelligible at the junction in the tiger preserve. We wave and move on.

posts.text: Havells… Wires that don’t catch fire.

posts.body: Violent thunderstorms on the plains last night. Calm in the morning.

And of course as I walk by the Contractor’s Association the guys out front pat a seat and next thing I know I’m hearing tales of government funding politics and drinking milk tea and they take me to see Durga and eat rice from a huge pot out of some bowl made from a leaf. Pretty typical evening in India, actually.

posts.caption: Take a picture they said. They did on their cellphones too. The effect is finished. Some of the flashes are lightning in the distance.
The chai guy took us to see a 28 ft tall statue of Kali set up for new year’s.

posts.body: Nepali street food. Awesome.

Out on the street. Deep fried something with onions and hot sauce. A circle of women in what looks like a store singing and drumming for an image of some god I don’t recognize. A cell phone recharge store. Onwards.
Haggled our room down on purpose this time in Alipurdaur. Muffler fixed in 45m and got that down by half too. Slowly getting the hang of India.

posts.text: We should have raised money for the **!!#$ highways, it woulda done more for the country

posts.body: Muffler again. No sooner did it go than we were waved down by a guy with a welding torch and a corrugated shack. While we were waiting for the weld to cool a jeep pulled up and he cut off the ladder on the back of the vehicle, throwing it behind the shack as they sped away.
Chai, chapati, and cold dal for lunch. Our host showed us the trick he taught the baby goat that wandered in.
Huge military presence here. The mounted border patrol forces appear to ride camels.
Shocked to see people in Siliguri wearing motorcycle helmets. Isn’t this India?
Hoping we don’t wind up at “MR. CHHANGS SUPER SPECIALITY HOSPITAL”. Typo aside, the top two floors don’t seem to have any windows.
Tea groves. Some kind of bugs making noises so loud we thought we’d blown our axle again.
Quick chai stop waiting at a train crossing and the day is starting to look much brighter.
Refueled with NASCAR efficiency but the fuel tanker still got past us and required overtaking a second time.

posts.caption: This explains why traffic on the bridge was down to one lane.

posts.body: A huge mess of guys scrambling up ladders onto the top of a bus like sailors into rigging.
Deployed emergency Skittles preserve. Seems to have helped a bit.

Early morning. Cool enough to wear a sweater. Disagreement last night over what time to start and a rough road. A child of eight or so walks beside us on the road carrying a bundle of leaves, barefoot.
Cold shower. Beard left a soot mark on the towel. No beer at state run hotels. Early bed tonight.
There’s so much diesel soot on my shirt it looks a different color. I could taste it as we were driving.
A stranger buys me a chai just down the street from a Jain clothing store and across from a gold merchant. No sign of a bakery, so back to the hotel for dinner.
Checked in to a state run hotel. Clean, but not terrible cheap by local standards. Smell of coal burning in the alley. Out looking for an ATM and snacks for tomorrow. Horns. So many horns.
Closing in on Raiganj and the end of our day.
Dragonflies hover over colorful cloth stalls in the valley below. Our third New Years.

posts.text: Have you guys ever been taken to the police station to have your passport photocopied? No, hunh. Well, last night was pretty much the worst night of my life.

posts.body: Got stuck in traffic just there behind three heavily laden ox carts.
Trucks are all painted with messages on their backs, like “PLEASE SOUND HORN PLEASE” or “obey the traffic rulls”. That was the first time I ever saw “ALL THE BEST” though.
Cool weather today. Maybe 25C? Mostly horrible roads. Starting to actually enjoy the madcap driving.
Met up with the team that hit the cow. Morale for them is rather low. Haggled the muffler re-repair down to 30 rupees from 100.

posts.text: Diesel

posts.body:
”…are there giraffes in India? ”
“No, I said GOATS EATING GRASS”

A lot gets lost in the 2’ separating us in the rickshaw, mostly we just hear horns 24/7
Lost a bolt off the muffler. Quick stop for that… And a chai if I can find one.
A man with no legs reaches out to us as we go by. I reach for change but with the bumpy ride, I don’t manage to get coins out in time.
Not in the least surprised a child is operating a full sized excavator.
Word from ahead is that the roads get worse. I’m hoping they don’t mean worse than this.
I buy three each of these deep fried mysteries. One of them is so good I go back for three more. Shaun is so delighted he heads back and buys ten.
A man plowing a field with two oxen just outside a modern hotel.
Fuel line came off the gas tank. Guess that explains why we ran out of gas a little earlier than expected.
Tense finish to the cricket after dinner and a beer with the other teams. Our friend Yvonne is at the game: hope she’s got an interpreter there!
The other team came back, by the way.
Hakka noodles for dinner; good, but I’d hoped for something more unusual. (Hakka are a migrant people from China who have spread over the world.)

posts.text: We’re driving alongside this motorcycle and we realize he’s pulled out his [censored] and he’s having a go!
I did not try the silver knob over the toilet. If you try that it might turn on the showerhead.

posts.body: One of the other teams decided that 1300 was too much to spend for three people and moved on. Suspect they’ll be back.
Now we’re watching Hindi Lord of the Rings.
News from the road: someone hit a cow and got a midnight warning to skip town.

posts.caption: The mayhem behind our rickshaw was disrupted by the arrival of a rickshaw with three ladies.

posts.body: Oh, and then it started working again.
Just rusted through our exhaust. We are now driving a huge chainsaw across India. 8k to the next town. Hope they have a mechanic who can fix this.
First gear is sounding rough. 24km to Suri, where we hope to spend the night and have the rickshaw looked at.
Skirting around a truly massive open pit coal mine.
Roads were much better on my driving shift. Still 140k left to our destination but a late lunch in a black-light lit restaurant got our personal engines refueled and we are back on the move.
Worst road we’ve seen in India yet. Making maybe 15kph.
People blocking the road handing out leaflets and asking for money. Religious? Political? No idea. They give me one but when we try to drive off they want it back.
Watching our nightly IPL game, planning tomorrow’s journey, and mucking around with the data I can get from the Adventurists’ site to see if I can learn anything interesting.
Tail end of a Bollywood Indiana Jones flick. The lads have gone to give the ‘shaw a check up.
The hotel is still under construction but broken windows go without repair. The play area outside has a pond which is a pit of mosquitos with a broken see saw. This is Tata’s steel town.
So many speed bumps on this highway.
At the border between Odisha and West Bengal. Traffic is light, amenities are sparse, and the potholes are huge.
Followed by a round of photos.
And then we gave our server at lunch our autographs.
Corridor of trucks stretches for a kilometer on both sides. Must be the border.

Quick overview of the trip so far. Today is day 8 of 14. We’ve traveled about 2500km, and have about 1500km to go. Morale is good. The rickshaw seems to be behaving well, and we are making good time on a heavy travel day. We’ve been following signs towards Calcutta for most of a week but will be swinging North soon as we leave Odisha and reach West Bengal.
India appears to be divided into regions controlled by different cement companies.
Now able to follow a game of cricket on TV. India is rubbing off on me.
Shaun drank the water. We’ll see how that plays out.
New Years again! Madness in the streets, a tent full of dancers making stops along the way. Constant horns from frustrated drivers. A man tells me the virtues of a guru named Baba.
Our hotel has a fancy hotel in the back and a cheap hotel out front. We ate thali at the cheap place up front much to the manager’s surprise and dismay. Good curries!

posts.text: Are we actually going to follow the plan tomorrow if we do?
posts.source: Aaron, to a suggestion that we plan our day

posts.body: Felt guilty about splurging on the nice AC room until I realized it was only about ten bucks each.
Turned back before the temple. It’s a rickshaw free zone, it seems.
Puri police pulled us over to inquire about our activities and our flag. Aaron defused the situation with grace and a reference to our charity work.

posts.caption: Ferry’s here.

posts.body: The locals all had red stained teeth from something or other they were chewing.

posts.caption: Tea and a snack while waiting for the ferry. Got here way early.

posts.body: Across! Slowest shortcut ever, but we’re back on the move.
Tea making lessons across the language barrier with Mr. Shaun.
Finally under way. Didn’t think they’d pack the ferry but boy was I wrong. We’re stuffed in between the bridge tower and the ramp winch. Aaron’s gone aloft to make friends with the crew.
Lots of people bating
The sign on the hut says “Cambridge College” but I am dubious that there is any formal relationship with the British school of the same name.

Lots of bathers in the ponds on the salt flats: people, birds, cows. We pass a temple and a priest with a money tray runs into the street shouting “hello hello” but we have a ferry to catch. The air smells of salt and mud and a cool breeze cuts across the rickshaw.
Way way more cows in the road today. Aaron is driving the rickshaw like a rally car to make our date with a ferry.
Back on the move. Salt flats and rice paddies on a back road headed to a ferry which might get us to Puri, the holiest Hindu city in all of India. Hoping to make the 10:30 ferry.

tags: Cottage with a view in Rambha.

posts.body: Managed 430km of distance today. Quite good.

Grandeur somewhat in decline. Wide-tailed birds cavort outside our lake-view cottage with its dusty veranda and painted brick walls. They bring us sweet lassis at my request, and ask what time we would like dinner.
Two cows literally butting heads across both lanes in the highway. Bird on the back of one is unperturbed.

posts.caption: Safety first. Note how the young man kept one hand on the van while shaking my hand.

posts.body: Tailwind. Green again. Hills layer the horizon and fade into the blue sky as they recede. We’re about to cross from Andrha Pradesh into Odisha.
Man in the median blows a whistle telling us to stop. We elect to continue.
Passed another team under tow, this time by a giant truck. Bum carburetor. Dangerous ride. Best of luck.
Field of sunflowers, heads nodding in the breeze.
Goat herders with straw parasols. The silent plains seem to have invaded the rickshaw. We say less.
Vast plains. Dry air and dry rice paddies. Head wind. Good progress.
Sobering report of a team hit by a bus. Broken arms, broken legs. No idea who. News came from a pair of kiwi rickshaws now with one under tow.
Just saw a cow eat a post-it note.
Air conditioning couldn’t explain the host’s chilly reception at lunch, but the other patrons were friendly and curious.

posts.caption: Just gave an engineering student a lift to school after a passing motorcycle asked if we would take him off his back.

posts.body: Just got pulled over by a couple civil servants in a sweet Ambassasor car. They wanted to hear our story and told us about how they run the largest bus fleet in the world. 22,000 buses. Guinness book of world records stuff.
An angry girlfriend screaming at your terrible driving sounds the same in every language.
Rooster cry at dawn. Long drive ahead today.
When we stay in nice places Aaron and Shaun share and I get my own room. In not so nice places we all share a room and I sleep in the mattress on the floor.
Arriving in Tuni at nightfall after going through the pass with clouds of diesel smoke billowing all around.

posts.text: I remember when Kolkata was more than a thousand kilometers away.

posts.body: Chased down by a car of kids who wanted to meet us and find out what we were doing. Finally figured it out on the third attempt.
Things seen carried by motorbike passengers today include a goat (very placid) and a full size house door (looked unstable).
The shortcut actually worked!

posts.text: We’re taking a short cut.

posts.body: Crossing irrigation dams to Rajamundry. Lush blue wetlands to our left, barren red dust plains on the right.

posts.text: How many places have you been where you have to carry a spare axle?

posts.body: Back on the road 3 hrs later.

We’re adjusting to the heat reasonably well. I’m not sweating through my clothes quite so fast, and 35 feels hot but not unpleasant now. That said, it’s pushing 40 today so napping in the shade is the order of the day.
Shaun and Aaron improvising a fix for the LED lights that broke on our harrowing drive into Gudur.
Nap interrupted by samosas. Worth it.
Mechanic went for lunch while we wait for power. Shaun has left the axle at the machine shop.
Waiting for the power to come back to be able to polish the axle. Should be in about 45m.

posts.caption: The bane of our existence.

posts.body: Becoming very familiar with the inside of a rickshaw axle.
Left axle smoking. Found a mechanic in Telegudu.
Reading local papers is one of my favorite travel activities.

Claire asked what our favorite foods have been so far. It’s hard to pick winners, but Indian breakfasts are much more savory than Western ones and don’t feature eggs. The idli (rice in UFO shapes) have been delicious dipped in sambar, but my favorite has to be the dosa we’ve been eating everywhere we go.

We’ve avoided meat for the most part, but I had a very nice prawn with mint curry in Pondicherry and a great mutton kati roll in Cochin that stand out.

So far, no “travelers disease” despite eating all kinds of things everywhere. Haven’t had dessert, really. By the time I finish my thali I’m usually stuffed. Unlikely to come home skinnier than I left.

No discussion of food would be fair without mentioning the chai everywhere served in little cups!
Correction! It is the Telugu New Year! There are apparently 12 different new years in India.

posts.caption: Arriving at dinner. We had to force our hosts to eat with us but as starving students they eventually gave in.

posts.body: Inside a bus you are invincible. I understand the horns much better having ridden. They are the driver demanding obedience; no more or less.
Don’t think I’ve seen another Westerner since Pondicherry aside from the teams we passed today.
Tourists don’t come here. Especially not on the public bus our adopted guides led us home on. People stared, but all wanted to know where we were from.
Ratsekar was shy because he was only 163cm tall, and was unsure in his English, but spoke surprisingly well.
The temple was crowded because it is Hindi New Year, BTW.
And then we took the two accounting students out for a super nice dinner and shared stories.

posts.text: Hello, Americans!

posts.body: Adopted by a couple kids studying for accounting school at the temple. Going for dinner with them.

posts.caption: Dots administered by the priests we encountered.

posts.body: Checked sandals and had protocol explained. In a queue for the 20 rupees version of the experience. Gold glitters, as does the city in the evening light. Feels simultaneously mundane and profound.
Arrived in Vijayawada. Million people. Staying in a corporate hotel because Shaun accidentally negotiated us a better deal.
Dodgy rickshaw driver renegotiated the rates after taking us to our destination, the temple. Dropped us at a bus up instead of the stairs. Figured it out and walked up.
Sure, why not park across both lanes of the off ramp while you go get a snack?
Funny kid had some guts trying to talk us out of twelve rupees for two tiny thimbles of chai. He was grinning from ear to ear for getting seven out of us.

posts.caption: A six lane highway, without the lanes.

posts.text: Nothing like lunch out a bucket.

posts.body: Even more teams at lunch. We must be in the thick of the pack.
Two separate motorcyclists patted the bag of rice they were carrying and shouted something. Maybe they think we need rice?
When our driver puts a hand out the right side of the rickshaw the rest of us know it’s to dry the sweat off from holding the throttle open for two hours.
Better keep moving. Don’t want to be in a clump of rickshaws. We’ll never see India like that.

posts.text: Nothing tastes like India more than two stroke oil and ice cream.

posts.body: Flagged down an ice cream auto and had a snack.
Just saw Muss Jack go past. We’re in the thick of things now.
Met up with Donkey Chote and Rapid Rickshaw Transit to catch up and celebrate 50,000k on the odometer.

posts.caption: The tune up in Pondi is paying for itself (all 700 rupee) now, 60km/h!!!!

posts.body: Caught up with Donkey Chote & Rickshaw Rapid Transit on the freeway past Nellore. It’s great to see some other teams…
Got under way by seven. Didn’t have the heart to wake the others earlier.
Signs shifting from Dravidian to Hindi script. Saw the first person wearing any kind of head covering that I can remember. Definitely getting farther north.
Just heard our Mongolian friends are still in Cochin due to mechanical problems. Shame. Hope they manage to ship themselves ahead and catch up.

Peter: I have an alarm set for six.
Shaun: Okay.
Aaron: Unfortunately, that's still ten hours from now.

dialogue.name: Peter
dialogue.label: Peter:
dialogue.phrase: I have an alarm set for six.

dialogue.name: Aaron
dialogue.label: Aaron:
dialogue.phrase: Unfortunately, that's still ten hours from now.

posts.body: Up to 100km per six liters of gas. Not great, but pretty good. Bet we’d do a lot better if we drove at a more reasonable rate.

It is not advisable to drive the rickshaw after dark. Or in cities. Or on roads under construction restricted to a single lane with potholes so big they can roll the vehicle. Especially don’t do all these things during rush hour while rolling into a town looking for a place to stay with no plan at all.

Avoid night driving. And city driving. And driving on roads which are under construction and only one lane wide. Also avoid driving into town with no plan of lodging. Especially avoid doing all of the above at once. Bottomed out the rickshaw going over a bump. Nearly rolled it a few times. Almost ran into several vehicles (and this is by the standards of someone who doesn’t even get his heart rate up in a near head on collision anymore).
Sad to report the Indian Space Port did not allow visitors.

So many beggars swarming the rickshaw in Gudur. We took everything out but the fuzzy dice. If those are there in the morning I’ll be amazed. Holed up in our room for a few. The contrast with Pondicherry could not be bigger.

posts.caption: This is as close as we get to launching into space from India

posts.body: Time for my driving shift. Gonna see if we can visit the Indian Space Center.
Back seat shouted but we still hit the speed breaker pretty hard.
So long Tamil Nadu! Hello, Andra Pradesh!
No big deal, just three women sweeping the center lane of the highway protected by a few cones.
I know they aren’t swastikas but they really LOOK like swastikas and it’s weird seeing swastikas painted up all delicate and pretty.

posts.text: Know safety, no injury. No safety, know injury.

posts.body: Fruit stand in the middle of the highway up against the rail.
Just lost a drag race to a bus. Well, we survived, so let’s call it a draw.
Dosa for lunch just before Chennai. Shopkeep impressed by our tolerance for spice.

A salmon is a fish that swims upstream to its hone waters. So too do the “salmon” of Indian highways, which see fit to occupy any lane they please while driving against the flow of traffic. While most salmon are simply two-wheelers on the shoulder we have seen rickshaws, cars, and even a huge truck in the innermost incoming lane.
Lovely chat with a woman adopted by Belgians out of a Pondicherry orphanage who now returns to India annually to help out with local development organizations.
Conversations between the rickshaw and passing motorcycles end with a handshake… While driving 50kph.
Coast road. Easy three hours to Chennai. Chennai will be rough driving. Knot practice in the back with leftover rope.
Walking along the shore, talking about our feelings under a gigantic statue of Mahatma Gandhi.

posts.caption: Sitting in my thinking chair with foot rest built in.

posts.body: Amazing dinner after getting the rickshaw back on her feet. Going for a walk and then to bed. We’re somewhere in the middle of the pack (we think?) and completion seems achievable. We just have to average about 250-300km a day based on our current forecasted route.
I do not smoke. (Since someone asked after the recent post.)
Back at the mechanics watching them repack grease into the back left axle. Deja vu.
A cow just walked by as placid as you please in rush hour traffic outside the parts shop.
Inquired at the hotel for a mechanic. Recognized the place by the dozen auto rickshaw carcasses on the side of the road. Hopefully we won’t find anything too bad.
Splurged on a room at the Hotel D'Orient. This is head and shoulders the nicest room I have ever laid eyes on. My god, what a treat.
Just saw another team go by. First time since Cochin.
Pondicherry. Damn. I could use a cigarette.
Definitely definitely took a chance with that truck stop lunch though.
Ate lunch off a banana leaf with my right hand’s fingers. Starting to get the hang of that. Almost to Pondicherry. Good pace today so far. Might take in the sights a bit.
Just paid a toll with a photo opportunity.
Somehow, at 55kmh we are among the fastest vehicles on the road and pass everything except buses (who blow past with their horns wailing) and the monster SUVs that seem so popular.
Three wheelers pay no tolls. Except to that one guy who told us “10 rupees”.

posts.caption: The hills east of Salem. Many are dotted with temples.

posts.body: Aaron’s tiger costume stinks so bad we insisted he move it away from other luggage.

Our six AM start turned into 7:30 but that’s still a 4hr lead over the last two days. I’m wearing my Frank Water shirt today (we’re still accepting donations to support bringing clean water to small villages) and we’ve managed to reconfigure our bags to make more leg room. Chennai, ho!

posts.caption: AC and dosas. Not bad.

posts.body: For a while there we had several dogs in a row go nuts and charge the vehicle as we’d go by. Super glad none of them managed to bite Aaron. Maybe it’s the shark mouth. Maybe it’s the ripe smell of three Canadians who spent all day in a rickshaw.
Chain hotel off the highway at Perunderai. Mango juice from the cool bar to relax. Planning to ride at first light tomorrow.
Driving in Indian cities at rush hour is not something I would recommend.
Down forty hairpin bends to return to sea level and our journey. The views were amazing and we weren’t even scrunched by a passing truck!
Rickshaw feels amazing after 3 hrs work from Pradeep and the good company of Paul. Thanks again, guys!

So, the knock in the front turned out that the bearings were shot. Also, the back left assembly (newly replaced by The Adventurists) had no grease at all in it and a broken emergency brake cable. Quality workmanship, that was. Did I mention the missing o-ring in the carb? Hoping to get about double the mileage now.

posts.caption: New bearings.

posts.body: Amazing breakfast with Frank, who escaped his old life sitting at computers seven years ago to move here and run a homestay and wilderness trekking business.

posts.text: This place is infested with leopards.

posts.body: Everyone wants to tell us what they do for a living. “Seaman”, “loading man”, and the like.

Woke up to find out we’re in the middle of the most incredible tea plantations. Had two cups of chai on a quick walk about as the sun came up. Shaun is working on getting the 12V plug working and Aaron has vanished to take photos. I’m writing updates and trying to find a 3-Wheeler mechanic.
Bare fluorescent bulb. Dead tired at 10pm. Need to have the front wheel looked at before we go any farther.
Arrived safe to Valparai in the middle of a wildlife preserve. So overwhelmed by it all. Got interviewed for the local paper by a couple reporters who followed us through town.

posts.caption: Obstacles on road…

posts.body: Took the scenic route. We were the scene some of the time.
Just exchanged confirmation that there were no elephants on the road with a pair of motorcycle driving kids. They looked much relieved. I guess elephants will mess you up.
Buses are terrifying. Utterly.

posts.caption: Wow

posts.body: Zap straps fix everything.
Out of Kochi. We are minor celebrities at every traffic light.

posts.text: Speed thrills, but kills.

posts.body: Missed the sendoff. Oh well.

posts.caption: Nervous energy abounds.
Amazing “lassy” with cardamon.

posts.text: Oh, if you go that way there might be a couple of bumps…

posts.caption: Dosa with sambar and coconut chutney.

posts.body: Home sunburned and danced out but well enough to drive tomorrow. From here on we keep the ocean (and Bangladesh) to our right until we reach Shillong.
DJ keeps playing two thirds if every track. Won’t dance. Tired of having my heart broken.
Okay, enough partying. We have serious work to do tomorrow.
And now it’s limbo time.
People are spitting all kinds of fire right now.

posts.caption: Knot practice.
Team Rickshaw annihilated by local “adolescents”. Guy from TV presented the award.

posts.body: TV crews throng. There’s the Guy From TV and his crew, the contest winners and theirs. Everyone feels a little tense. Met one woman who thought they’d only be driving 4-5hrs per day… And they’re going the long way.

posts.caption: Chai and a samosa while we watch our back left wheel assembly get replaced.

posts.body: Ah, the daily 7:30AM power outage.

posts.caption: Fancy dinner out.

posts.body: Phone internet achieved!

posts.title: Aaron's blog
posts.description: Aaron writes in longer form and shoots in higher resolution.

posts.body: Golden sunset. Strange birds and bats overhead, floating in our roof top pool. It smells like rain but stays dry. Some discussion of routes and such. The party begins tomorrow at 2pm and the run the morning after.
Three hours of effort has taught me a lot about the Indian cell phone system but has not resulted in a working 3G plan.

posts.caption: Shaun’s first drive.

posts.body: Turmeric stained fingers after a Keralan fish lunch with Yvonne, Aaron’s Swiss diplomat friend. They’re swapping stories of building collapses in Dar es Salaam. After ten years abroad she’s returning to Switzerland and bringing her British Enfield motorbikes with her.

posts.caption: Our steed: the tiger with the mouth of a shark.

posts.body: My phone has internet! It’s slow as hell, but better than nothing.
Amazing chickpea curry over coconut rice for breakfast. The Western alternative was an omelet. Lame.
Tried to negotiate with the shop. They wanted 25 for a bottle of water. I offered 60 for 3. Not gonna happen. Left thirsty. Need to work on my bargaining skills.
Semi dry state. Drinks at the wet bar and angry about the foreigner price. Four dollars for a beer!?

posts.caption: The Mongolian Banditos!
Mutton mughlai paratha.

posts.body: No, a bowl with a hole cut in the bottom is not a suitable alternative to a funnel for refueling. Thanks for trying, Mr. PVC Pipe Man.
Ran out of gas two minutes into our first ride. At least, we think that’s all it is. A passing rickshaw driver took the others to fill a jerry can.

posts.caption: Our chariots have arrived.

posts.body: The nice lady at the photo shop touched up the bags from under my eyes for the picture I needed to get a SIM card.

posts.caption: Horn tutorial.
You have to be more gentle.

posts.title: A reader asks: How hot is it?
posts.body: Well, the locals are complaining. Also, I’m considering my fluid intake in liters of sweat per day. Today’s forecast was for 34C and no, it isn’t a “dry” heat.

posts.caption: The Starting Line!
Traffic all backed up in the bazaar.

posts.caption: And then we found some of the rickshaws. There’ll be 77 teams, it seems. But there are only 22 here so far.
The old ways and the new juxtapose everywhere in India.

posts.text: Someone has played upon you a terrible trick!
posts.source: Aaron’s seat-mate when our quest was explained to him

posts.body: Sixteen hour flights are what tedious plodding Japanese RPGs were made for.
4am cab ride is giving me a taste of Indian collaborative driving.

posts.caption: Aaron’s camera bag is about the same size as my main luggage. Glad I left my camera behind.

posts.body: Flight to Kochi. Just got sprayed down by… something. It’s so perfectly safe that they advised people with contact lenses to keep their eyes closed throughout and suggested breathing through a handkerchief. No immediate effect.
Boarding. Next stop, Dubai. So long, America.

dialogue.phrase: Boarding. Next stop, Dubai. So long, America.

posts.caption: Walking to BART. This is really just a “before” picture.

posts.title: The plan
posts.body:
Fly to Cochin, Kerala, India.
Collect a 7hp three wheel rickshaw.
Drive 4000km across India to Shillong.

posts.title: The team
posts.body:
Aaron (Expedition Leader). Internationally renowned photographer, civilian pilot in a war torn country, and globe wanderer extraordinaire.

Shaun (The Mechanic). Trained as a pilot, able to rebuild an airplane from a bag of rivets, capable of making even Volkswagen engines run. Sailor, electrician, outdoorsman, cricketer.

Peter (Ballast). Able to balance out the back seat of a rickshaw so all three wheels contact the roadway. Your faithful chronicler.
Pack weight is 30 lbs. Could probably cut five but this is good. My to do list is empty. We are on.
Just weighed in at 201. Curious to see what this month does to my weight.

posts.caption: Just shy of thirty pounds. Might try and cut it back a bit further.
